results.title: Wuthering Heights
results.creator_credit: Samuel Z Arkoff and Robert Fuest
results.brief_description: Based on Emily Bronte’s novel of defiant young lovers and set in the 18th Century amidst the harsh realities of the Yorkshire moors. This version is considered a good and realistic treatment of Bronte’s novel with authentic locations. Starring Timothy Dalton as Heathcliff and Anne Calder-Marshall as Cathy.

results.title: Wrong world
results.creator_credit: Seon Film Productions, Bryce Menzies and Ian Pringle
results.brief_description: After rejecting the conventional career path of a successful practice, an idealistic young doctor recalls, 8 years later, time spent in Bolivia, drug addiction and a trip across America. During a course of rehabilitation in Melbourne he meets a young woman, an addict and petty thief. The recollection of this indeterminate journey suggests the disconnected process of memory. The title suggests how the different worlds in which the doctor has travelled in search of meaning have only increased his sense of dislocation. Photographed by Ray Argall. Cast includes Richard Moir and Jo Kennedy.

results.title: Wrong way Butch
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Peter Smith and David Barclay
results.brief_description: Peter Smith, aided by Dave O’Brien as a factory operative who never does the right thing, offers some hints on industrial safety. As in the NFB of Canada “Accidents don’t happen” series, a humorous approach is successfully used to sweeten important lessons. Both a good comedy and an excellent training film for machine-tool workers, apprentices and pupils in technical schools.

results.title: Wrong side of the road
results.creator_credit: Inma Productions, Australian Film Commission, Ned Lander and Graeme Isaac
results.brief_description: Provides an insight into what it’s like to be young and black in Australia by introducing two rock bands “No Fixed Address” and “Us Mob” and following them through two days on the road. The film is punctuated by run-ins between the young musicians and white authority. “Wrong side of the road” shows a courageous minority standing up to a racist society, the close relationship within the black community and the respect given to women within this community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Inma Productions, Australian Film Commission, Ned Lander and Graeme Isaac

results.title: Wrong Kind of Black
results.brief_description: From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the 70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath).

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

results.description:
From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the ‘70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan, in a career-making performance) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath). This four part high end digital drama comedy series brings a rare perspective to a tumultuous era in Australia’s history, one that resonates just as strongly today.

At the height of the ‘70s disco inferno, Monty is Melbourne’s hottest DJ. Dubbed ‘The Black Superman’, Monty spins tunes at the Albion Charles Hotel where he and younger brother Paul rub shoulders with a motley crew of Russian mobsters and Aussie yobbos alike. The ‘fro and the flares seem like worlds away from Monty’s childhood on remote Palm Island – but beneath the surface, not much has changed. Aboriginal culture is still not welcome in white society, and the price of its preservation can be deadly. As tensions escalate and trouble keeps finding the two brothers, Monty decides that enough is enough and takes his future into his own hands.

Although the Wrong Kind of Black takes us back to the 1960s and ‘70s, this personal account is as much the story of Indigenous Australia today as it was back then. It is a story of extremes – heartbreak and triumph, unconditional love and blind hatred, innocence and wisdom, black and white – always told with great humour and an enduring sense of hope.
description_for_label:
From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the ‘70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan, in a career-making performance) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath). This four part high end digital drama comedy series brings a rare perspective to a tumultuous era in Australia’s history, one that resonates just as strongly today.

At the height of the ‘70s disco inferno, Monty is Melbourne’s hottest DJ. Dubbed ‘The Black Superman’, Monty spins tunes at the Albion Charles Hotel where he and younger brother Paul rub shoulders with a motley crew of Russian mobsters and Aussie yobbos alike. The ‘fro and the flares seem like worlds away from Monty’s childhood on remote Palm Island – but beneath the surface, not much has changed. Aboriginal culture is still not welcome in white society, and the price of its preservation can be deadly. As tensions escalate and trouble keeps finding the two brothers, Monty decides that enough is enough and takes his future into his own hands.

Although the Wrong Kind of Black takes us back to the 1960s and ‘70s, this personal account is as much the story of Indigenous Australia today as it was back then. It is a story of extremes – heartbreak and triumph, unconditional love and blind hatred, innocence and wisdom, black and white – always told with great humour and an enduring sense of hope.

results.title: Written on the wind [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Universal International Pictures, Albert Zugsmith and Douglas Sirk
results.brief_description: The son of a rich Texas oil family seems bent on self-destruction despite the apparent steadying influences of two outsiders who have been drawn into the family. It is, however, in the character of his sister, Marylee, that the conflict between society’s repression and individual needs is focused. Sirk’s mise en scene intensifies the genre’s conventions in such a way as to make the inherent contradictions unusually explicit. The final scenes - the inquest and after - virtually form an epilogue which brings out ambiguities on how Marylee is to be seen in relation to the bourgeois couple (Hudson and Bacall). This displaces the conventions of the happy ending which often open a gap between the credible resolution of conflict and the apparently irreconcilable. Based on the novel of the same name by Robert Wilder. Cast includes Rock Hudson, Lauren Bacall, Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone.

results.title: Writing: the new. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education, Daryl Wayland and David Zweck
results.brief_description: The new general writing section of HSC English distinguishes between argumentative and imaginative writing tasks and creatice writing. This program explores comments on these tasks and provides some guidence for their management. Presented by Peter Couchman.

results.title: Writing: making meaning
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Bob Scarfe
results.brief_description: Looks at the process of teaching children to write in the postprimary school by focusing on teaching methods of three teachers. Stresses that writing for meaning comes first and mechanics of writing second. Narrated by Diane O’Connor.

results.title: Writing, plain and fancy
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions, Severo Perez and Mallory Pearce
results.brief_description: Surveys the evolution of written communication. Beginning with the Romans and their invention of capital letters, the program continues through the reign of the great King Charlemagne who standardized the alphabet. The importance of legible writing for good communication is stressed. Narrated by John Houseman.
